In 1891, the [[Salvation Army]] opened up its own match factory in Bow, London, using harmless red phosphorus and paying better wages.<ref name=spartacus /> Part of the reason behind this match factory was the desire to improve the conditions of home workers, including children, who dipped yellow phosporus-based matches at home.{{fact}} Several children died from eating these matches.

The [[Bryant and May]] factory received bad publicity from these events, and in 1901 they announced that the factory no longer used yellow phosphorous. Ironically, Francis May and [[William Bryant]], who were both [[Religious Society of Friends|Quakers]], opened their own match factory specifically to make safety matches. They started using red phosphorus in 1855, but could not compete against the much cheaper yellow phosphorus-based matches. The Salvation Army had the same problem, their own matches were three-times the price of yellow-phosphorus-based matches; but many of their supporters refused to buy yellow phosphorus-based matches.
